The roles and responsibilities of individuals who work with children depend on the job duty/title and level of interaction.

  • All members of the university community (including students, visitors, vendors, and guests) must:
    • Comply with the conduct requirements in this policy (see Module 2).
    • Report suspected child abuse to CPS, and/or law enforcement, and to the University Director of Public Safety immediately.
  • University employees, students who interact with children as part of their work-related duties or academic program, vendors, visitors and guests using university-owned or leased property must:
    • Engage in appropriate conduct when working with children.
    • Remove a child from dangerous or potentially dangerous situations immediately.
    • Report suspected child abuse to CPS, and/or law enforcement, and to the University Director of Public Safety immediately.

• Individuals engaged in managing or supervising programs where children are present must:
    • Implement procedures related to the duty of care including:
      • appropriate supervision at all times
      • protection of childrenâ€™s health and safety
      • appropriate use of protective equipment
    • Report suspected child abuse to CPS, and/or law enforcement, and to the University Director of Public Safety immediately.
    • Keep state licenses (e.g. child care center) current and prominently displayed if required within the campus unit.
  • Administrator/Fiscal Agent in Charge of the Program must:
    • Communicate the requirements of this policy when approving use of university space for University sponsored programs that include children.
    • Address instances of inappropriate conduct effectively.
    • Report suspected child abuse to CPS, and/or law enforcement, and to the University Director of Public Safety immediately.
    • Communicate the requirements of this policy to all staff.
  • University Director of Public Safety and his/her designee must:
    • Report suspected abuse to CPS and/or law enforcement.

title.EN: Maintaining and Submitting a Program List

content1.EN:
• University sponsored programs that include children, and units responsible for university facilities that are used by programs including children, must maintain an up-to-date list of those programs.
  • The program list should include:
    • Program dates, times, and locations
    • attendance (age range and number of participants)
    • program contacts so that in the event of an emergency consideration may be given to the possible presence of children and the appropriate course of action to address their health and safety
  • At least seven days prior to the start of a new program, the responsible university unit must also submit this information to the University Director of Public Safety.

[IMG canstockphoto16285526.jpg]

Organizations unrelated to the University that utilize University owned and leased facilities for programs which involve children must:

  • conduct criminal background checks, using appropriate data sources, on each of their employees, volunteers and representatives who participate in the programs.
  • implement their own supervision, conduct, and reporting requirements.
  • exclude persons from participating in the program if their background check uncovers a criminal conviction or information concerning child abuse.

Terms and conditions of contractual agreements with parties unrelated to the University concerning use of University facilities for programs involving children must include a requirement that the unrelated party fulfill the duties outlined above.

When appropriate, such contracts will also include an indemnification provision in which the University is held harmless for the inappropriate or unlawful acts or omissions of any individual participating in a program.
